etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in The Wycliffite Bible (early version). From post-classical Latin onycha ingredient of incense consisting of the opercula of marine molluscs (Vulgate) from Hellenistic Greek ὄνυχα, accusative of ὄνυξ

definitions: An ingredient of incense used in Mosaic ritual, consisting of the opercula of marine molluscs, which emit a penetrating aroma when burnt.
